channel.title: Exercise 1: Customers on English
channel.description: Recent content in Exercise 1: Customers on English

item.title: Step 1: Explore Senzing
item.description:
Understanding Senzing Workshop Resources

Before diving into mapping, it’s valuable to understand what resources Senzing provides to help you succeed. In this step, you’ll explore the senzing/ folder structure and learn about the tools and references available.

Open the Workshop Folder

First, open the workshop folder in your IDE to see the project structure.

In your IDE file explorer:

  1. Navigate to the workshop/ directory
  2. Expand the folder to see its contents

item.title: Step 2: Generate Schema
item.description:
First: Examine Your Source Data

Before generating the schema, you need to understand your data structure and business goals.

Open the customer CSV file:

In your IDE file explorer (left sidebar), navigate to:

  1. Navigate to the workshop/workspace/customers directory
  2. Expand the folder to see its contents
  3. Double-click customers.csv to open it in your IDE

Review the data structure:

  • Scroll through the first 10-20 rows
  • Note the column headers
  • Observe data patterns and completeness
  • Look for different customer types (Individual vs Company)
  1. Define your business objective:
    • Are you trying to find duplicate customers?
    • Will you match this against other datasets?
    • What constitutes a “match” for your use case?

Remember: You guide the AI - understanding your data and goals ensures better mapping results.

item.title: Step 4: Validate Mapping
item.description:
Run the Mapper on Full Dataset

Now that you have a mapper, test it on the complete customer dataset to generate the Senzing JSON output.

Execute the Mapper

Tell Amazon Q: Run the mapper on the actual data

Q will execute the mapper, run the linter, and run the JSON analyzer - all steps documented in the Senzing tools reference.

Managing AI Context

If the analyzer output doesn’t show errors or warnings, the AI may have lost context during the long conversation. When this happens, re-add the context using the @ symbol.

item.title: Step 5: Load Data
item.description:
Configure and Load Data into Senzing

Now that your mapping is validated, configure the DATA_SOURCE and load the customer data into Senzing for entity resolution.

Step 1: Add the DATA_SOURCE

Ask Amazon Q: Add the data source for me

Step 2: Load the Mapped Records

Ask Amazon Q: Yes to the prior question, or load the mapped customer records into Senzing

item.title: Step 6: Analyze Resolved Data
item.description:
Capture and Analyze Entity Resolution Results

After loading data, take a snapshot and analyze how Senzing resolved your customer records. You’ll explore statistics, understand match patterns, and investigate specific entity examples.

Part 1: Take Snapshot

Generate the Snapshot

Ask Amazon Q: Yes to the prior question, or take a snapshot

Understanding the Results

Key Result: 120 records â†’ 78 entities

This means Senzing identified 42 duplicate records (35% compression), consolidating them into their true entities.

item.title: Step 7: Key Takeaways
item.description:
The Power of Agentic AI

Throughout this exercise, you experienced a fundamentally different way of working with development tools. Instead of memorizing commands, navigating file systems, and context-switching between documentation and implementation, you simply described what you wanted to accomplish.

What Changed

Traditional Workflow Friction:

  • “What directory is that file in again?”
  • “What was the command syntax for this tool?”
  • “Where did I save that output?”
  • “What step comes next in the process?”
  • “How do I format this configuration file?”

AI-Assisted Workflow:
